_meta.description: Core principles that all DAHAO domains must inherit. Locked principles cannot be violated by any domain.

@purpose_primacy.statement: All decisions within a DAHAO instance must serve its stated purpose.
@purpose_primacy.lock_reason: Without purpose alignment, DAHAO loses coherence and meaning.
implications: Every proposal must demonstrate how it serves purpose
Changes that undermine purpose are automatically invalid
Purpose can only change with near-unanimous consent (95%)

@democratic_evolution.statement: DAHAO evolves through collective deliberation, not unilateral decision. No individual or entity has privileged authority over values.
@democratic_evolution.lock_reason: Prevents capture by any single interest. Ensures legitimacy through participation.
implications: All changes require community consensus
No contributor can force changes alone
Every voice can participate in dialectic

@transparency.statement: All proposals, discussions, votes, reasoning, and changes are publicly visible and auditable.
@transparency.lock_reason: Hidden governance is illegitimate governance. Accountability requires visibility.
implications: Full version history maintained forever
Vote records are public
Reasoning for decisions must be documented
No secret deliberations

@precautionary_default.statement: When uncertain about potential harm to stakeholders, err toward protection rather than risk.
@precautionary_default.lock_reason: The cost of failing to protect exceeds the cost of unnecessary protection.
implications: Each domain defines what 'harm' and 'protection' mean
Uncertainty favors caution
Protection ratchet enforces this at governance level
@precautionary_default.note: This is the meta-principle. Domains apply it to their specific context.

@evidence_based.statement: Claims about reality must be supported by evidence, weighted by quality.
@evidence_based.rationale: Prevents unfounded assertions from driving decisions.
implications: Proposals require evidence
Evidence quality affects weight
Contradicting evidence triggers deeper review
@evidence_based.note: Unlocked because domains may adjust evidence requirements.

@protection_asymmetry.statement: Adding protections for stakeholders is easier than removing them.
@protection_asymmetry.mechanism: Removing protection requires 1.5Ã— the consensus threshold of adding it.
implications: DAHAO naturally evolves toward more protection
Economic/political pressure cannot easily remove protections
Expanding moral circle is easier than contracting it

@fork_freedom.statement: Anyone may fork any DAHAO instance and modify it according to their values.
@fork_freedom.rationale: Freedom to exit ensures voluntary participation. Diversity enables experimentation.
implications: Forks are legitimate, not defections
Different values can coexist in different forks
Main branch represents consensus, not absolute truth
Forks may propose innovations back to main

@good_faith.statement: All participants are assumed to be acting in good faith toward the stated purpose.
@good_faith.rationale: Collaborative governance requires trust as default.
implications: Assume charitable interpretation of others' positions
Disagree with arguments, not people
Bad faith can be demonstrated, but not assumed

@inheritance_integrity.statement: Domain instances must not violate core locked principles, even through domain-specific additions.
@inheritance_integrity.lock_reason: Ensures all DAHAOs share fundamental governance legitimacy.
implications: Domain proposals checked against core principles
Conflicts with locked principles auto-reject
Domains can be stricter than core, never looser
